## Introduction

In this analysis, we build a model predicting sale prices of houses
based on data on houses that were sold in the Duke Forest neighborhood
of Durham, NC around November 2020. Let's start by loading the packages
we'll use for the analysis.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code  code-summary="Packages"}
library(openintro)  # for data
library(tidyverse)  # for data wrangling and visualization
library(knitr)      # for tables
library(broom)      # for model summary
```
:::


We present the results of exploratory data analysis in @sec-eda and the
regression model in @sec-model.

<!--# ADD CITATION HERE -->

## Exploratory data analysis {#sec-eda}

The data contains 98 houses. As part of the
exploratory analysis let's visualize and summarize the relationship
between areas and prices of these houses.

### Data visualization

@fig-histogram shows two histograms displaying the distributions of
`price` and `area` individually.


::: {#fig-histogram .cell .column-page-right layout-ncol="2"}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(duke_forest, aes(x = price)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 50000) +
  labs(title = "Histogram of prices")

ggplot(duke_forest, aes(x = area)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 250) +
  labs(title = "Histogram of areas")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![Histogram of `price`s](authoring_files/figure-html/fig-histogram-1.png){#fig-histogram-1 width=672}
:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![Histogram of `area`s](authoring_files/figure-html/fig-histogram-2.png){#fig-histogram-2 width=672}
:::

Histograms of individual variables
:::


@fig-scatterplot displays the relationship between these two variables
in a scatterplot.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(duke_forest, aes(x = area, y = price)) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(title = "Price and area of houses in Duke Forest")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![Scatterplot of price vs. area of houses in Duke Forest](authoring_files/figure-html/fig-scatterplot-1.png){#fig-scatterplot width=672}
:::
:::


### Summary statistics {#summary-stats}

@tbl-stats displays basic summary statistics for these two variables.


::: {#tbl-stats .cell tbl-cap='Summary statistics for price and area of houses in Duke Forest'}

```{.r .cell-code}
duke_forest %>%
  summarise(
    `Median price` = median(price),
    `IQR price` = IQR(price),
    `Median area` = median(area),
    `IQR area` = IQR(area),
    `Correlation, r` = cor(price, area)
    ) %>%
  kable(digits = c(0, 0, 0, 0, 2))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
| Median price| IQR price| Median area| IQR area| Correlation, r|
|------------:|---------:|-----------:|--------:|--------------:|
|       540000|    193125|        2623|     1121|           0.67|
:::
:::


## Modeling {#sec-model}

We can fit a simple linear regression model of the form shown in
@eq-slr.

$$
price = \hat{\beta_0} + \hat{\beta_1} \times area + \epsilon
$$ {#eq-slr}

@tbl-lm shows the regression output for this model.


::: {#tbl-lm .cell tbl-cap='Linear regression model for predicting price from area'}

```{.r .cell-code}
price_fit <- lm(price ~ area, data = duke_forest)
  
price_fit %>%
  tidy() %>%
  kable(digits = c(0, 0, 2, 2, 2))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
|term        | estimate| std.error| statistic| p.value|
|:-----------|--------:|---------:|---------:|-------:|
|(Intercept) |   116652|  53302.46|      2.19|    0.03|
|area        |      159|     18.17|      8.78|    0.00|
:::
:::
